review.title: Intelligent bidirectional rapidly-exploring random trees for optimal motion planning in complex cluttered environments
review.abstract: The sampling based motion planning algorithm known as Rapidly-exploring Random Trees (RRT) has gained the attention of many researchers due to their computational efficiency and effectiveness. Recently, a variant of RRT called RRT* has been proposed that ensures asymptotic optimality. Subsequently its bidirectional version has also been introduced in the literature known as Bidirectional-RRT* (B-RRT*). We introduce a new variant called Intelligent Bidirectional-RRT* (IB-RRT*) which is an improved variant of the optimal RRT* and bidirectional version of RRT* (B-RRT*) algorithms and is specially designed for complex cluttered environments. IB-RRT* utilizes the bidirectional trees approach and introduces intelligent sample insertion heuristic for fast convergence to the optimal path solution using uniform sampling heuristics. The proposed algorithm is evaluated theoretically and experimental results are presented that compares IB-RRT* with RRT* and B-RRT*. Moreover, experimental results demonstrate the superior efficiency of IB-RRT* in comparison with RRT* and B-RRT in complex cluttered environments.
histories: The article is published in Elsevier Journal of Robotics and Autonomous Systems
review.COMMENTS: The article is published in Elsevier Journal of Robotics and Autonomous Systems

metadata.title: Intelligent bidirectional rapidly-exploring random trees for optimal motion planning in complex cluttered environments

sections.text: The sample-based motion planning algorithm, known as Rapid-exploring Random Trees (RRT), has attracted the attention of many researchers due to its computational power and effectiveness. Recently, a variant of the RRT called RRT * was proposed that ensures asymptotic optimality. Subsequently, its bidirectional version was also introduced in the literature as Bidirectional RRT * (B-RRT *). We introduce a new variant called Intelligent Bidirectional RRT * (IB-RRT *), which is an improved variant of the optimal RRT * and bidirectional version of the RRT * (B-RRT *) algorithms and is specifically designed for complex, confusing environments. IB-RRT * uses the bidirectional construction approach and introduces intelligent heuristics for sample insertion to achieve rapid convergence to optimal path resolution using unified sampling hayristics to theoretically evaluate the proposed algorithm and algorithm.

sections.text: The RRT * algorithm provides asymptotic optimality. With respect to algorithm 1, the RRT * algorithm begins its iterative process after the preliminary initialization process by sampling the random sample xrand from the given configuration space Xfree (line 3). Afterwards, the RRT * finds the set of nearby vertices Xnear from the tree centered in the ball region. If the set of nearby vertices Xnear, calculated by the NearestVertices algorithm, is empty, then the sentence Xnear is filled in by the NearestVertex algorithm (lines 4-6). The populated sentence Xnear is then sorted by the GetSortedList algorithm to form a list of shapes (x ′, c), ordered in ascending order of the cost function c (line 7).

sections.heading: 6.1 Probabilistic Completeness
sections.text: In any configuration space, an algorithm is considered probabilistically complete if the probability of finding a path solution approaches it when the number of samples from the configuration space reaches infinity. It is known that the RRT is a probabilistically complete algorithm than its optimal variant RRT * [13]. Since our proposed IB-RRT * algorithm performs the random sample function exactly like the above algorithms and is only a bidirectional version of the RRT * with intelligent sample insertion, it can reasonably be said that it also inherits the probabilistic completeness property of the RRT *.

sections.heading: 6.2 Asymptotic Optimality
sections.text: It is known that the RRT * and its variant RRT-Connect do not guarantee optimal convergence to an optimal solution, even if the number of iterations is increased to infinity [13]. However, the RRT * is an optimal variant of the RRT, which ensures an almost certain convergence to an optimal solution [12]. As explained above, the IB-RRT * attempts to connect both trees, Ta = (Va, Ea) and Tb = (Vb, Eb), in each iteration. A random sample xrand is used as a connection point between the two trees (Figure 1 (d)), if it turns out that the sphere region centered at the edge contains near corners of both trees, i.e. va, Va, Va: va, Bxrand, r and vb, Vb: vb, Bxrand, r. A similar procedure is applied by the RRT * algorithm [12] in order to generate the random sample for the connection between the selected algorithm and the parent part of the RRT *, since no additional connection between the RRT and the parent part of the algorithm is required.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions and Future work
sections.text: This paper presents a detailed comparative analysis of the performance of our proposed IB-RRT * algorithm with the existing RRT * and B-RRT * algorithms. It has been demonstrated, both analytically and experimentally, that our proposed algorithm i) has an almost computational complexity similar to RRT * and BiRRT *; ii) provides near-certain convergence to the optimum path solution; iii) has a higher convergence rate, which means that it quickly approaches the optimum solution compared to the two state-of-the-art RRT * and B-RRT * algorithms; iv) uses less memory to approach the optimum solution, using lower iterations and using up memory for each iteration. This paper also presents path planning problems where the original RRT * algorithm does not achieve the optimum path solution within a reasonable boundary of iterations. Experimental results that support theoretical analysis are also presented in this paper.

Therefore, in order to derive efficient solutions for motion planning in the practical world, the Rapidly-exploring Random Trees (RRT) algorithms [23] have been extensively explored.

However, RRT* is an optimal variant of RRT, ensuring almost-sure convergence to an optimal solution [12].
A similar procedure is employed by the RRT* algorithm [12] to connect the random sample with its chosen parent.
Biasing the samples for rapid convergence to the optimal solution is computationally inefficient, specifically in higher dimension configuration spaces [13].
Lemma 1 ([13]) A sampling-based algorithm ensures asymptotic optimality, such that P(limi→∞ ‖σ′ i − σi‖ = 0;∀σi, σ′ i ∈ ∑ free) = 1.
For the incremental or wavefront expansion of the trees it is proven that the regions near the point of generation of trees are more dense [23].
Furthermore, trees connection heuristic employed by B-RRT* [11] is partially greedy, similar to the the connect heuristic [20].
Furthermore, trees connection heuristic employed by B-RRT* [11] is partially greedy, similar to the the connect heuristic [20].
It has already been proved that if the bidirectional version of RRT* uses purely RRT-Connect heuristic [20] for the connection of two trees, it is no longer asymptotically optimal [11].
It has already been proved that if the bidirectional version of RRT* uses purely RRT-Connect heuristic [20] for the connection of two trees, it is no longer asymptotically optimal [11].
This happens because when only the connect heuristic [20] is used, an edge originating from Ta for example, tries to reach the closest vertex on Tb.
It has already been proved that both procedures have to run in logi expected time [12].

Furthermore, while IB-RRT* makes its best effort to increase the cardinality of the near vertices, the number of near vertices per tree returned by the procedure NearVertices cannot exceed a constant number [12].
The proof for theorem 3 is exactly the same to one provided for the computational ratio of RRT* and RRT in [12].

metadata.abstractText: The sampling based motion planning algorithm known as Rapidly-exploring Random Trees (RRT) has gained the attention of many researchers due to their computational efficiency and effectiveness. Recently, a variant of RRT called RRT* has been proposed that ensures asymptotic optimality. Subsequently its bidirectional version has also been introduced in the literature known as Bidirectional-RRT* (B-RRT*). We introduce a new variant called Intelligent Bidirectional-RRT* (IB-RRT*) which is an improved variant of the optimal RRT* and bidirectional version of RRT* (B-RRT*) algorithms and is specially designed for complex cluttered environments. IB-RRT* utilizes the bidirectional trees approach and introduces intelligent sample insertion heuristic for fast convergence to the optimal path solution using uniform sampling heuristics. The proposed algorithm is evaluated theoretically and experimental ∗This is the authors’ version of the paper published in Elsevier Robotics and Autonomous Systems Journal. The source code of this paper is available at: github.com/ahq1993. results are presented that compares IB-RRT* with RRT* and B-RRT*. Moreover, experimental results demonstrate the superior efficiency of IB-RRT* in comparison with RRT* and B-RRT in complex cluttered environments.
